tips.title: Social Login
tips.summary: Prioritize the sign-in option that best matches the user's context and show it in the primary slot.
details: Social login boosts conversion since users can easily join your platform.
Then, it's a good practice to put your social login on top of the page and place the email password authentication below.
Beware that privacy-oriented people prefer not to use social login then it's always good to have another option for them.

tips.title: Design Better Menus
tips.summary: Avoid traditional menu bars; place menu options in locations that make sense for the layout.
details: Menus have readability issues very often
A quick hack to make them look and function better is to add an icon next to every action. In that way, you help users visually identify actions without having to read the whole copy.
Also, it's a good practice to highlight the active tab, if it's applicable to the menu's use case.

tips.title: The Gutenberg Principle
tips.summary: Keep key information in the upper-left and bottom-right to reinforce emphasis.
details: The Gutenberg Principle (aka Z-Pattern Layout) states that users' eyes travel according to a Z-shaped path from the top-left area to the bottom-right area.
It's a good practice to place your CTA at the end of this flow to lead users to take action.

tips.title: Delete Modal
tips.summary: Use a modal only when the action is irreversible.
details: Pay extra attention to your buttons' copies.
Avoid generic out-of-context copies, like 'Yes' or 'No'.
Instead, use a sentence to communicate clearly the button's actions.

tips.title: Align Uneven Elements
tips.summary: If inner content is left-aligned, the outer elements should be left-aligned too.
details: In many cases, you have to align uneven in size elements.
Even if you set the spacing between the elements to be the same, the visual result seems off.
The best way to fix this visual issue is by setting the same width for all the elements.

tips.title: De-emphasize Dangerous Actions
tips.summary: Style cancel or destructive alternatives in muted tones to prevent accidental clicks.
details: Always try to de-emphasize dangerous actions like deletion.
You have to prioritize the default action instead of the dangerous/irreversible one.
Also, use more than one trait to make the element look like a secondary action (color, size, type, placement, etc).

tips.title: Always Have A CTA
tips.summary: Every page should include a clear call-to-action so users know what to do next.
details: Always have a CTA button on your website's above the fold section
Many of your visitors might never scroll down your landing page
So you need to offer them an option to convert immediately.

tips.title: The Perfect Header
tips.summary: Group the heading and subtext as a single unit to improve readability.
details: A good header needs to put attention on the title and then lead the reader to the description, which must be readable.

tips.title: Validate Deletion
tips.summary: For irreversible actions, require users to type a specific word to confirm.
details: Never allow the user to delete something without validation.
People misclick all the time, and losing information forever hurts and creates a bad memory related to your product!
Make sure your UI supports (inline or popup) deletion validation.

tips.title: Empty State With Templates
tips.summary: Offer templates so users understand the expected content structure.
details: Upgrade your UI empty states with templates!
Instead of redirecting people to create content from scratch, make their lives easier.
Use pre-made templates to help them experience your product's value quicker and boost your product adoption at the same time.

tips.title: Inform Users Beforehand
tips.summary: Warn users about impactful changes using clear banners or popups.
details: Never let users guess what's the next step on your user journey.
Have in mind that conversions might be low because people are afraid to press a button.
A strong message (like "Reserve") adds stress and makes people wonder whether they'll be charged or not.

tips.title: How to Align Uneven Items
tips.summary: Match element alignment to the alignment of their inner content.
tips.notes: Duplicate concept of Align Uneven Elements.

tips.title: Fallback for Transparent Avatars 1
tips.summary: Add a background layer when an avatar image has transparency.
details: Many platforms (like Twitter) allow PNG avatars that can cause UI inconsistencies
To avoid this problem add a subtle border and background color to the avatar that is the same as the app's background.

tips.title: Fallback for Transparent Avatars 2
tips.summary: Use a background color to avoid transparent avatars blending into the UI.
tips.notes: Duplicate concept of Fallback for Transparent Avatars 1.
details: Another visual hack to ensure consistency for transparent avatars is by adding a subtle border around them, the same color as the background.
The border looks like it's part of the background and distinguishes it from the cover section.

tips.summary: Use a consistent radius scale; a common heuristic is outer radius about 2x inner radius.

tips.title: How to Apply the Brand Color
tips.summary: Apply brand color to key actions like primary CTAs and important icons.
details: Colors are a core element for any user interface.
One of the most common mistakes in UI design is the over usage of the brand color.
Avoid it by highlighting only the most important elements of your interface with your primary color.

tips.title: Distinguish Selected Items
tips.summary: Highlight selected items so they clearly stand out from unselected ones.
details: Always make sure that your selected items are easily identified at a glance.
Changing the background color is a simple and accessible way to achieve it!
It makes the user experience better since the user can easily figure out which elements are already selected.

tips.title: Use Better Link Button
tips.summary: Make the primary action visually dominant among links or buttons.
details: Links are important and you need to treat their appearance nicely.
Many times a traditional button works better than a single link.
Especially if the link is not on a header, footer, or the body of an article.

tips.title: Use Consistent Buttons
tips.summary: Keep primary buttons consistent in shape and styling across the UI.
details: Your design, and mostly your buttons, need to be consistent thought the user interface.
Keep this in mind especially for the header (hero) section.
Don't confuse your visitors with different buttons in styles and copy.

tips.title: Direct User Attention with Media
tips.summary: Place a supporting video or visual next to the CTA to draw focus.
details: Leverage visuals to direct user's attention
As humans, we tend to follow another person's line of sight.
Take advantage of this effect, by prompting people to focus on individual elements (A) or scroll (B).

tips.title: Prompt User to Scroll
tips.summary: If key content starts below the fold, show a down arrow to encourage scrolling.
details: Your website needs to prompt users to scroll to communicate your product's value better.
Especially when the header content is not enough to describe your product's value.
A simple hack to prompt users to scroll is by showing them a glimpse of the next section.

tips.title: Highlight The Best Offer
tips.summary: When multiple plans exist, visually emphasize the recommended option.
details: Always highlight your best pricing plan and make it pop out.
In that way, you help users identify the most used plan and you promote your top offer. It's a win-win situation.
To highlight the plan, use more than one design ways, eg. color, size, elevation (aka shadow)!

tips.title: Avoid Fullwidth Paragraphs
tips.summary: Limit paragraph width to improve readability.
details: Long lines can bore users and create readability problems.
Fix it by limiting the line's width between 500px and 700px.
Instead of pixels, you can restrict the character number per line as well.

tips.title: Make Cards Look Clickable
tips.summary: Add stronger shadows, arrows, or hover states to signal clickability.
details: In many cases, cards fail to indicate that they're clickable.
Designers omit CTA buttons and only count on the user's experience or/and, hover effects.
In design, it's always a good practice to never leave things on user imagination.

tips.title: Make Inputs Self-Explanatory
tips.summary: Provide short examples under inputs to clarify expected values.
details: The two "secret" weapons to enhance your input fields are the placeholder text & its type.‚†Ä ‚†Ä

tips.title: Pick The Correct Element
tips.summary: Use high-contrast, bright colors for CTAs to separate them from surrounding UI.
details: Make it as simple as possible for users to enter their information.‚†Ä ‚†Ä Choosing the right UI element plays a huge part in upgrading UX.‚†Ä ‚†Ä For example, use a number picker for integer numeric values instead of a generic text field.
In eCommerce carts, most users will buy 1, or 2 items maximum. The -/+ buttons make their input process quicker.
Get notified about new tips & articles before anyone else!

tips.title: How To Enhance Hierarchy
tips.summary: Use size, weight, and color to emphasize key content sections.
details: Visual hierarchy is important in design because it boosts the user experience and leads the user attention
Your No.1 priority is to make your primary action (aka CTA) prominent.
In this case, the button that initiates the booking process is the main CTA.

tips.title: Make Tooltips Responsive
tips.summary: On mobile, allow tap/press to reveal tooltips instead of hover.
details: The classic tooltip is activated once the user hovers over the element...
On desktop, this works perfectly!
However mobile devices don't support the hover effect

tips.title: Choose Chart Types Carefully
tips.summary: Select chart types that match the data and improve clarity.
details: Line charts might look trendier but they don't apply to every case.
When the x-axis has limited options, a bar chart is the most appropriate graph type.
Plus, the line chart might introduce false intermediate values.

tips.title: Padding On Rounded Cards
tips.summary: Increase internal padding so content stays away from rounded edges.
details: The left cards use the same padding around the card. Yet the visual result seems off.
A quick fix is to make the padding larger when the element on the edge is not round - like icons and text.
The rule of thumb is to use double the padding on the edge which is not round.

tips.title: Visually Distinguish Elements
tips.summary: Use dividers, subtle borders, or background colors to separate elements.

tips.title: Support Icons With Labels
tips.summary: Add labels when icon meaning is not obvious.
details: Icons can often confuse users or get misinterpreted by different people due to their experience level or even due to their culture.
Fix this accessibility issue is by adding a subtle text label near the icon which will describe its usage.
Keep this information in mind especially for mobile interfaces which don't support hover effects.

tips.title: Use Labels Cleverly 2
tips.summary: Use labels to clarify choices when users must select from options.
details: A smart use case for labels is on color pickers with predefined values.
Depending on the app's context you can even omit labels.
Consider keeping them for color-blind people who struggle to identify colors though.

tips.title: Use Labels Cleverly 1
tips.summary: Use labels to clarify specific information you need from the user.
details: Complement your link copy with a visual representation of the selected value. In this example, the labels show you how capitalization will look.
It's not always possible to do this hack, so go all into it when the opportunity presents itself.

tips.title: Display Useful Shortcuts
tips.summary: Show keyboard shortcuts for power users on desktop platforms.
details: Keyboard shortcuts boost productivity and save time for power users.
Yet it's sometimes difficult to remember them.
Take advantage of Fitts's law* and place your shortcut keys next to the action button.

tips.title: Prioritize UX
tips.summary: User needs come before business goals in product decisions.
details: Instagram recently launched Shop.
The decision to place it at the position of the Activity tab is not random...
This might lead to better conversions but make the user experience x10 worse.

tips.summary: Separate sections with backgrounds, borders, or dividers.
